ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I reviewed and expanded upon my economics skills, with a new direction toward distributive justice (contra other Econ classes at Yale). I enjoyed thinking deeper about the philosophical and practical meaning of equality, and how different conceptions might contribute to different social structures.
I learned about the lives and work of various egalitarian theorists.

How to work with economic models attentive to equality and distribution. These models are relatively simple economically, but deeper philosophically. How to reason more rigorously about distributive justice.
Very interesting linking class between philosophy and actual economic models.
I learned about different social welfare theories and socialist theories.
Learned about economic models for taxation and labor and how to think about equality in policy.
ideas of distributive justice by different philosophers, plus some basic economic models to play out their ideas

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is much more lecture than seminar, but I think that is fine as the opportunity to listen to Prof. Roemer is worth two hours weekly. I found the grading system for the problem sets confusing, and there was not much clarity about how our grades would be calculated.
I think it was one of the best classes that got into why we care about equality from an ethical standpoint.
Could be improved with more planning and consistent pacing, but it was very very interesting. I would have like more class discussion however.

strengths
-material and interdisciplinary approach
-professor Roemer is very friendly and open to meeting with you in office hours

weaknesses
-lecture structure: professor Roemer just reads from the screen and it can get monotonous

Strengths: Topic super interesting

Weaknesses: class did not have engaging discussion
strengths: lots of interesting discussions and ideas; weaknesses: lecture could be more engaging than reading off of a Word document

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I would. If you are worried that your quantitative and philosophical skills aren't both up to par, this course makes a great credit/D. It is certainly worth the opportunity to learn from a professor of different values/ideology than most faculty in his departments.

I think the difficulties in the course scheduling and the theorists that we read made it hard to recommend this course to anyone that doesn't already have an intellectual investment in Rawls, Dworkin, Cohen etc. If your intellectual training has already caused you to move beyond them  (i.e. to Marxian thinking), there's no reason to go back.
I would if you are interested in the course material and syllabus. If it doesn't sound interesting, then don't take it.
If you're interested in equality or Roemer, yes.
yes, it's an interesting course with some interesting ideas
